fw.hi:
DOANE ROBINSON
116 E. SUMMIT AVE.
PIERRE, S.D.

div1.p: I am delighted to have your letter and to know of your good health and growing position in American letters. I have read the Messiah and find it an important section of the cycle. Every section is fine, but I think there is a bit more action in the Indian Wars than elsewhere. I have no criticism, but I have thought that in some way the American nation should be called to step forward and feel the trill of the cyclorama. That does not make my meaning clear. I want to get it into the cosnsciousness of America in a way that they will point to it with a proprietory gesture and shout in a prideful way; "This is our show."

I am certain that old Homer would be burned up with jealousy if he could rise up long enough to read the cycle. I see you have addressed the Messiah to Mona. It was coming to her. Do you have Mona and the kiddies with you in Saint Louis, or are they still parked at Branson? Will is running all over Missouri every month and I want him give you my greetings direrect.

I am not doing much to the Sioux History. Just plugging up a few holes. I have maintained on what I regarded as authority that the unspeakable Inkapaduta was present and in direction of a band of Isantees and Yanktonais, at Little Horn. This statement has caused a lot of criticism; as good a scholar as Dr. Folwell, the Minnesota historian, has said that the statement is unfounded, but I have found the Sissetons and other South Dakota bands are firmly of the popinion that I am right. When CrazyHorseCrazy Horse returned to Fort Robinson in the spring of 1877 He gave an interview to the Chicago Times, classifying the bands by villages and leaders, and he said unoqivicallyunequivocally that the sixth village counting up stream waas composed of Santees and Yanktonais, under Red Point the Santee. I am glad to have this with opportunity to stress the historic fact.

I wonder if it will be my good fortune to look upon your kind face again. It would be a joy to do so, but you will understand that I cannot be so ubiquousubiquitous as formerly. I am not dispondent but at

lg.l: Its not so dreary as 'twould seem;
Old age,—God given time to dream.

div1.p: With warm affection and all wishes for contentment for you and yours,
